Mouselet Don't you have to be flying with BA to use the BA lounge? Spending that much extra to get cheaper drinks seems far from the path of wisdom?
Pseudonym @RA I meant that they only hired women, doesn't sex discrimination law block that? Maybe there's some kind of get out for events?
Pharma @REF!, agreed. It is either cut-throat competition, or the simple acknowledgement that one price does not fit all. National chains that charge the same in the South East and the North East are undercharging the former, and overcharging the latter.

ours don't seem to do much domestically, to be fair

BE11:19am

But then, guidance is always a tad cautious.

Xanthine @Pseudonym - presumably the argument would be that the event only asked for women so the independent hostess agency genuinely only had jobs for women. Both sides passing the buck, so to speak. I don't know how legally robust that would be if it was really challenged.
Tom Dalgleish FT copped a lashing in Wetherspoons riposte

Mouselet 'must be either better food or better atmosphere than Wetherspoons' is just pushing the other pubs to try harder
11:20 am
BE11:21am

And, clearly, there's a problem with expecting 6% LFL growth constantly in a sector that's flatlining at best.

BE11:21am

No comment on margins also, which is a new policy.

BE11:21am

Let me grab Barclays' notes on the conference call.

MonkeyTrader Wetherspoon numbers are interesting....LFLs look great as they continue to pare back the non-performing pubs. What really is telling is the lack of de-leveraging. Company points to debt being 30m higher year on year. So they cannot delever even when LFLs are >6.0%....
11:21 am
BE11:21am

· PBT being “slightly ahead” of expectations was confirmed as being ahead of Bloomberg consensus rather than last year. Bloomberg consensus is for PBT of £99.2 vs Barclays PBT forecast of £97m.

· Fewer pub closures expected in H2, so LFL sales and total sales growth will converge.

· The order and pay app. Still early days, but going well, it represents low single digits of revenue. The spend per head on the app is higher, but this reflects more food orders. Compared with non app orders involving food, the spend per head is similar.

· Wetherspoon commented that they are not introducing the app to improve spend per head, they are doing so to improve customers satisfaction, which we see as consistent with their ethos. Labour costs are actually higher as staff have to take drinks to the tables.

· Pizzas have been rolled out to c15% of pubs and are being trialed. The offer is definitely popular with customers, and the company expects to do a few more pubs serving pizzas as an extended trial before committing fully on a nationwide rollout. Unsurprisingly, the company would not be drawn on the degree to which pizza sales were incremental vs a substitute. Whilst margins are not a focus for Wetherspoon, the fact that gross margin on pizzas is high should be good for cash profit, in our view, if the rollout took place nationwide.

· The company expects FY18 to be H1 weighted from a PBT perspective, given a number of cost headwinds (National Living Wage increases, business rates, sugar tax, etc) come in during H2.

· The Football World Cup. Previous World Cups since the company has started to show games have delivered at best LFLs in line with pre World Cup trends, or at worst LFLs c1-2% lower. The key drivers for World Cup revenue are i) the times of the games (which are good) and ii) the performance of domestic teams.

· Potential restrictions on alcohol sales at airports. The company commented that food, soft drinks, coffee etc are major revenue contributors at airports, and so it didn’t expect much of an impact from any potential restrictions.

Valuation: Wetherspoon trades on a Dec-18 PE 18.9x, EV/EBITDA 10x, FCF yield (pre new site capex) 8.2%

The story here is largely of promise and delivery. Here's Neil Campling, now of Mirabaud.

BE11:48am

The short term issue with the rebalancing of component inventory is the significant impact on short term earnings estimates. Most of the 3D supply chain is yet to report and should enjoy strong CQ4 numbers to reflect the initial iPhone X build ramp. However, the outlook for Q1/Q2 could show a significant deterioration if 3D module company LG Innotek guidance is anything to go buy. LG Innotek reported its best-ever quarterly operating profit in 4Q17, up 153% QoQ, with sales +61% QoQ driven by the (Apple related) optical solution division – enjoying 101% QoQ sales growth.

Lefevre @Piggy, we had falling prices in late 19C, I think industrial revolutions can do that, we don't always control prices when so much is coming from China, or digital platforms that don't even charge. G Tett good on this
11:48 am
BE11:48am

But for 2018, guidance implies substantial declines in profitability in H1 before an H2 rebound. The street will likely need to take H1 operating profit estimates down by 30% while leaving H2 estimates unchanged. So the ramp and OP leverage is still expected in H2 2018, but from a much lower base than originally expected.

BE11:50am

Currently the highest operating profit growth forecasts for IQE are for H1 2018 (+131% YoY) rather than H2 2018 (+41% YoY or 13% 6M on 6M). Given the increasing risk of the push out of the 3D ramp from H1 18 to H2 18 the stock is at risk, in our view, of significant profit shortfalls in the first half of 2018.

BE11:57am

Fever-Tree's January trading updates highlights another year of strong growth across all regions. The Board expects full year growth of 66%, leading to reported revenue of ~£169m. This is 7% ahead of consensus expectations of £158m for FY17. In the UK (49% of Fever-Tree revenue) , the board expects full year growth of 96%. The statement highlights that Fever-tree gained significant market share from its competitors, which should alleviate some of the concerns around a more competitive environment, which had weighed on shares in the second half of 2017. Revenue growth in Continental Europe (29% of Fever-Tree revenue) is expected to be 42% in FY17, which implies a modest slowdown in H217. In the United States (18% of Fever-Tree revenue) , management expects +39% growth in the full year

BE12:00pm

Fever-Tree reported strong FY17 sales of £169m, implying 58% growth in 2H17 (10% ahead of consensus). UK was very strong with organic growth of 87% in the second
half coming in significantly ahead of our expectations (+53%) with the company flagging it has become the number one mixer brand by value in the UK off-trade
channel. USA came in at +36% in H2 (broadly in line with our expectations of +34%) whereas Continental Europe at +25% in 2H17 was below our expectations (+37%).
The company’s strong performance in 2H17 in the UK suggests the Schweppes re-launch has not created major disruptions so far. Although this partly mitigates our
concerns about a sudden intensification of the competitive activity in the UK (around 50% of Group’s sales) we also believe it is still too early to dismiss the potential
threat given the ini al rollout was only at the end of last year. Consequently, we maintain our more cautious stance and Sector Perform, Speculative Risk rating.
